channel.title: CBC Top Stories -News -MSN CA
channel.description: "MSN.ca news has up-to-the-minute breaking news, current events, latest headlines, photos, analysis & opinion on top stories from Canada and around the world

item.title: Canada Job Grant NHL playoff ads deliberately pitched to men
item.description: An internal report on the spots also reveals that the content of the ads was deliberately pitched to men, rather than women, who were watching the hockey playoffs.

item.title: Trinity Western blasts N.S., Ontario law societies
item.description: At issue is Trinity Western's requirement that its 3,600 students sign a community covenant forbidding intimacy outside heterosexual marriage, which has been criticized as discriminatory against gays and lesbians.

item.title: Corporate Canada pays low taxes but contributes in 'lots of other ways'
item.description: Corporate Canada is often derided for not paying its fair share in taxes, but one of its top advocates argues that the corporate income tax rate doesn't give a full picture of how Canadian businesses contribute.

item.title: Iron Sheik plans to meet Rob Ford during Hot Docs festival
item.description: Wrestling star The Iron Sheik plans to meet with Toronto Mayor Rob Ford while he's in the city to promote his latest project at the Hot Docs film festival.

item.title: Canadians in 7 cities protest N.B. abortion clinic closure
item.description: Pro-choice protesters are rallying in Montreal, Toronto, Fredericton, Ottawa, Halifax, Charlottetown and St. John’s to protest the closure of New Brunswick's Morgentaler abortion clinic.

item.title: 3 roadblocks to the robocalls probe — and their possible fixes
item.description: Investigators ran into several problems in trying to probe allegations of misleading or nuisance calls across Canada in 2011. Here are three challenges identified by investigators, and how they might or might not be fixed under Bill C-23.

item.title: Harley Lawrence’s death leads to 1st-degree murder charges
item.description: Two people face first-degree murder charges in the death of Harley Lawrence, the man whose body was found in a burning bus shelter in Berwick, N.S., last fall.

item.title: South Korea ferry: all 15 crew members linked to disaster in custody
item.description: South Korean officials have now detained the entire navigating crew of the ferry that sank earlier this month. The 15 crew members, including the captain, are accused of negligence and failing to help passengers in need.

item.title: Alistair MacLeod laid to rest near Dunvegan home
item.description: Alistair MacLeod will be laid to rest today in an area of Cape Breton that he introduced to the world in his writing.

item.title: Nets withstand Raptors' furious late bid to take Game 3
item.description: Toronto came roaring back from a 15-point deficit with four minutes left in Brooklyn on Friday night, but free throw misses haunted the Raptors in a 102-98 loss.

item.title: Temporary foreign worker moratorium: 'We will see some restaurants close'
item.description: A moratorium on hiring temporary foreign workers for the food service industry could force the closure of restaurants and put Canadians out of work, industry experts say.

item.title: Harley Lawrence killing points to troubling trend
item.description: The death of Harley Lawrence at a bus stop in Berwick, N.S., for which two men have been charged with first-degree murder, adds another victim to the growing list of homeless people targeted in attacks across North America and around the world.

item.title: CMHC to limit mortgage insurance product offerings
item.description: Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation has announced it will no longer offer mortgage insurance on second homes, as it continues its review of the mortgage loan insurance business.

item.title: Foreign worker program abuse won't be tolerated, Jason Kenney warns
item.description: The government's decision to impose moratorium on the fast-food industry's access to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program will send employers "a very clear message" that abuse will not be tolerated, says Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: G7 imposes more sanctions on Russia
item.description: G7 leaders announced Friday that they will be imposing additional sanctions on Russia over the ongoing crisis in Ukraine.

item.title: 6 ways to fix 'maxed out' Everest
item.description: National Geographic contributor and Everest climber Mark Jenkins proposes six ways to solve the problems with Mount Everest.

item.title: Canadian court documents posted online, via Romania
item.description: Running a Google search on your own name might turn up some unwelcome results if you’ve ever been in court — thanks to a website in Romania.

item.title: Airbus tests prototype of electric airplane
item.description: Airbus successfully tested a prototype electric plane, dubbed the E-Fan, in Bordeaux, France, Friday. Click on the video to see footage from the test flight.

item.title: Minecraft players can now explore Denmark
item.description: The entire country of Denmark has been recreated to scale in the virtual world of Minecraft as an educational part of the Danish Geodata Agency's belief in topographical data transparency

item.title: Netflix to be a channel on 3 U.S. cable networks
item.description: Netflix's internet video service is about to join the programming lineup of three small cable-TV providers in the U.S., a breakthrough that acknowledges the growing popularity of online entertainment.

item.title: Stephen Harper says Senate reform is off the table
item.description: Significant reform of the Senate as well as the question of whether the upper chamber can be abolished are "off the table," Prime Minister Stephen Harper says.

item.title: First Nations activists join anti-Keystone XL rally in Washington
item.description: A flash-mob round dance in Washington, D.C., organized by an anti-Keystone XL group included dozens of Canadians who say indigenous voices must be heard in the protest against the proposed pipeline.

item.title: 4 Paris policemen arrested over alleged rape of Canadian woman
item.description: French media report four police officers are in custody in connection with the alleged rape of a Canadian woman at the Paris police headquarters.

item.title: Airbus tests prototype electric airplane
item.description: Airbus successfully tested a prototype electric plane, dubbed the E-Fan, in Bordeaux, France, Friday. Click on the video to see footage from the test flight.

item.title: Disney races to restock Frozen merchandise
item.description: Disney's hit film Frozen has become so popular that the entertainment giant's licensees can't make enough dresses, dolls and toys fast enough. But is that a marketing mistake or pure business genius?

item.title: Deadly STD makes crickets extra frisky
item.description: It's a sexually transmitted disease worthy of a horror movie - one that renders its six-legged victims infertile, but ramps up their desire to mate.

item.title: N.S. law society grants conditional approval for Trinity Western grads
item.description: Nova Scotia's bar society has voted to conditionally approve Trinity Western University's proposed new law school a day after barristers in Ontario ruled not to accredit the faith-based institution.

item.title: Miki Mappin discovers sex identity change creates passport hassles
item.description: A Saskatoon woman hoping to travel overseas has encountered a bureaucratic nightmare related to travel documents: She is transgender and no longer identifies as a man, so updating her passport is a major hassle.

item.title: Rare footage shows High Arctic Franklin-era shipwreck from 1853
item.description: Members of the Canadian Armed Forces have captured new underwater footage of the Breadalbane, a merchant ship that sank in the Barrow Strait in the High Arctic in 1853.

item.title: Four Paris policemen arrested over alleged rape of Canadian
item.description: French media report four police officers are in custody in connection with the alleged rape of a Canadian woman at the Paris police headquarters.

item.title: 2 men, 2 youths charged in alleged sex assaults on 4-year-old girl
item.description: Two men and two youths have been charged in connection with alleged multiple sexual assaults on a four-year-old girl over several years, Toronto police say.

item.title: Foreign workers fill more than just fast-food jobs, Jason Kenney says
item.description: Canadian employers hire temporary foreign workers to fill more than just jobs in the food sector and shutting down the Temporary Foreign Worker Program would have negative consequences for the Canadian economy, says Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: Privacy commissioner's office loses sensitive data
item.description: The Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada has lost an unencrypted hard drive containing salary information of about 800 current and former employees.

item.title: Pierre Poilievre offers vouching alternative in elections bill
item.description: Minister of State for Democratic Reform Pierre Poilievre says he's open to an amendment to the fair elections act that would allow people without ID showing their address to sign an oath proving their residence, among other major changes he announced Friday.

item.title: Ottawa posts $5.1B surplus in February
item.description: The federal treasury has reported its biggest monthly surplus since the recession, suggesting that Ottawa will handily beat the current fiscal year's deficit projection the government released in last month's budget.

item.title: Four Paris policemen arrested over the alleged rape of Canadian
item.description: French media report four police officers are in custody in connection with the alleged rape of a Canadian woman at the Paris police headquarters.

item.title: Foreign workers hired to fill more than just fast-food jobs, Jason Kenney says
item.description: Canadian employers hire temporary foreign workers to fill more than just jobs in the food sector and shutting down the Temporary Foreign Worker Program would have negative consequences for the Canadian economy, says Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: Harley Lawrence death: Arrests in case of homeless man found in bus shelter
item.description: RCMP have arrested two people as part of the police investigation into the death of homeless man Harley Lawrence in Berwick, N.S., in October.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Some children's bodies misidentified
item.description: As visiting President Barack Obama offers South Koreans his condolences for the ferry disaster, the South Korean government concedes that some bodies have been misidentified and announces changes to prevent such mistakes from happening again.

item.title: Senate reform can't be done by Ottawa alone
item.description: Parliament cannot go it alone when it comes to substantial Senate reform, the Supreme Court of Canada said in a unanimous decision released today. That puts a significant roadblock in the way of nearly all reforms proposed by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, who called the ruling a "decision for the status quo."

item.title: Longtime Liberal Herb Gray eulogized in Ottawa
item.description: A funeral was held in Ottawa today for longtime Windsor Liberal MP Herb Gray, who died Monday at the age of 82.

item.title: Anti-immigration flyers upset Brampton residents
item.description: Peel Regional Police are investigating allegations of racism over an anti-immigration pamphlet being circulated in Brampton, Ont.

item.title: Paul Walker's brother Cody continues late actor's legacy
item.description: Since Fast and Furious star Paul Walker was killed in a car crash last fall, his brother Cody has helped complete his role in the latest Furious feature, aided in promoting his final film Brick Mansions and worked on his nonprofit organization Reach Out WorldWide.

item.title: Longtime Liberal Herb Gray eulogized today in Ottawa
item.description: A funeral will be held in Ottawa today for longtime Windsor Liberal MP Herb Gray, who died Monday at the age of 82.

item.title: CRTC mulls cable rule overhaul that may allow custom packages
item.description: Canada moves a step closer to pick-and-pay cable television packages for consumers, with the broadcast regulator revealing its thoughts on how best to open up the industry to more customization.

item.title: Prince George ends Australia tour with Will and Kate
item.description: Britain's Prince William and his wife, Kate, ended their 10-day tour of Australia on Friday with veterans' day commemorations in the national capital.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Lavrov accuses West of plotting to seize control
item.description: Accusing the West of plotting to control Ukraine, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov declared Friday that the pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine will only lay down their arms if the Ukrainian government clears out the Maidan protest camp in Kyiv.

item.title: The value of a target benefit pension plan
item.description: The federal government unveiled its pitch for target benefit pension plans, with characteristics that put it in the middle, between defined benefit and defined contribution plans.

item.title: Harley Lawrence death: Arrests made after homeless man found in bus shelter
item.description: RCMP have arrested two people as part of the police investigation into the death of homeless man Harley Lawrence in Berwick, N.S., in October.

item.title: Disney race to restock Frozen merchandise raises questions
item.description: Disney's hit film Frozen has become so popular that the entertainment giant's licensees can't make enough dresses, dolls and toys fast enough. But is that a marketing mistake or pure business genius?

item.title: Temporary Foreign Worker Program for fast-food sector suspended by Ottawa
item.description: Employment Minister Jason Kenny has announced an immediate moratorium on the fast-food industry's access to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program.

item.title: Barack Obama weighs tougher North Korea sanctions
item.description: U.S. President Barack Obama says it may be time to consider further sanctions against North Korea "that have even more bite."

item.title: Supreme Court's Senate ruling: What to watch for
item.description: Friday morning's decision from the Supreme Court of Canada on Senate reform will either be the last word for a generation on changing the Senate or a blueprint about how the Red Chamber can be remade. Here's a look at what to watch for.

item.title: Net neutrality plan would lead to two-speed internet: Don Pittis
item.description: The FCC's recent musings on ending net neutrality could spell the end of what makes the internet great — that it's an all-you-can-eat buffet for some, but an occasional delicacy for others, Don Pittis writes.

item.title: Maclean's alleges 'disturbing' levels of sexual assault in Canadian military
item.description: The country's top military commander has ordered an internal review of programs and policies to combat sexual violence following a report published in Maclean's magazine that says assaults in the Canadian Forces have reached epidemic levels.

item.title: Eve Adams nomination race gets nastier
item.description: The riding nomination fight between Conservative MP Eve Adams and Natalia Lishchyna is growing nastier, with Lishchyna giving party officials an estimate of Adams's expenses that suggests she's gone over her spending limit.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines MH370: seabed search set to widen
item.description: The seabed search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet is set to widen as a sonar scan of the most likely crash site deep beneath the Indian Ocean nears completion without yielding a single clue, authorities said on Friday.

item.title: Alberta tour operator faces lawsuit over African misadventure
item.description: An American woman is suing the owner of Canmore-based Berg Adventures International, claiming two members of her party climbing Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa were drugged and robbed. Company owner Wally Berg says he will fight the lawsuit.

item.title: What to watch for in Supreme Court's Friday ruling on Senate
item.description: Friday morning's decision from the Supreme Court of Canada on Senate reform will either be the last word for a generation on changing the Senate or a blueprint about how the Red Chamber can be remade. Here's a look at what to watch for.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Russia's credit rating cut by S&P
item.description: The Standard & Poor's credit agency on Friday cut Russia's credit rating for the first time in more than five years, raising the financial stakes flowing from the crisis in Ukraine as tensions rise and the United States and its allies are contemplating further economic sanctions.

item.title: Simon Ostrovsky, U.S. journalist held in Ukraine, now free
item.description: Simon Ostrovsky, the U.S. journalist who was being held by pro-Russian gunmen in eastern Ukraine, was freed Thursday.

item.title: Whitehorse family's rescued puppy turns out to be a fox
item.description: A Whitehorse family got a little wild surprise this week when it turned out the abandoned puppy they rescued wasn't a puppy at all but most likely a fox.

item.title: Tim Hortons breaks with franchisee, expands foreign worker oversight after wage theft claims
item.description: Tim Hortons has expanded oversight of the use of temporary foreign workers at its franchises and taken over two locations in Fernie, B.C., and Blairmore, Alta., months after several employees told CBC News the owner of the two franchises took advantage of their status as temporary foreign workers to cheat them out of overtime pay.

item.title: Trinity Western law school rejected by Ontario law society
item.description: The Law Society of Upper Canada has voted 28 to 21against the accreditation of Trinity Western University's proposed new law school in B.C. That means law graduates from the B.C. university would not be able to practise in Ontario.

item.title: Australian pilot reports hijack attempt on flight to Bali
item.description: The pilot of a Virgin Australia plane flying to the Indonesian holiday island of Bali reported a hijacking attempt on Friday after a passenger tried to enter the cockpit, an Indonesian transport official said.

item.title: Pamela Wallin regrets paying back full amount Senate claimed she owed
item.description: In her first in-depth interview since her suspension from the Upper House last fall, suspended Senator Pam Wallin says she now regrets paying back the full $150,000 that Senate auditors determined she owed for questionable travel expenses.

item.title: Grand & Toy to close all 19 retail stores
item.description: Grand & Toy, the Toronto office supplies chain, will close down all 19 of its retail locations in Canada after 132 years in business.

item.title: Robbed on a Guatemalan roadside, Calgary man videotapes scary ordeal
item.description: A Calgary man and his British girlfriend who were robbed at gunpoint in Guatemala captured the entire frightening ordeal on camera.

item.title: Avril Lavigne defends Hello Kitty music video
item.description: Canadian pop singer Avril Lavigne has defended her brightly coloured video for Hello Kitty against charges of racism.

item.title: Keystone XL protesters get wet, but not arrested, in D.C.
item.description: Members of the Cowboy and Indian Alliance managed to pull off an anti-Keystone XL pipeline protest in the reflecting pool that lies in front of the famous Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., on Thursday without getting arrested.

item.title: Tim Hortons breaks with franchisee after foreign workers claim wage theft
item.description: The head office of Tim Hortons has taken over two franchises in Fernie, B.C., and Blairmore, Alta., months after several temporary foreign workers told CBC News the owner cheated them out of overtime pay.

item.title: Syria conflict: U.K. police urge Muslim women to stop would-be extremists
item.description: British counterterrorism police have launched an unprecedented appeal to Muslim women, urging them to dissuade relatives from travelling to Syria to fight with extremist Islamist groups and to report any concerns about their family members’ intentions.

item.title: Exploiting animals on Kijiji nets Calgary woman $7,000 fine
item.description: Ashley Onen of Calgary has been fined $7,000 for her role in an online scam. The city's humane society says the woman used various aliases to get free animals on Kijiji, neglected them and later resold them.

item.title: Pierre Poilievre says amendments coming to elections bill
item.description: Democratic Reform Minister Pierre Poilievre took the podium at the Chateau Laurier in Ottawa today to talk about "the facts" surrounding his controversial bill to rewrite Canada's election laws and then asked his audience, "So what is all the fuss about?"

item.title: Michael Pineda suspended 10 games for pine tar use
item.description: New York Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda was suspended for 10 games Thursday after being caught using pine tar. He said he won't appeal the penalty that will cost him two starts.

item.title: Temporary Foreign Worker Program linked to joblessness: report
item.description: The government's Temporary Foreign Worker Program nudges the unemployment rate higher in some sectors of the economy and parts of the country, think-tank C.D. Howe says in a report.

item.title: Good Samaritan gives his shoes to barefoot bus passenger
item.description: An off-duty Coast Mountain bus driver says it was a bus ride he'll never forget, after seeing a stranger give the shoes off his feet to a barefoot passenger in Surrey, B.C.

item.title: Robocalls made across Canada in 2011 won't bring charges
item.description: An investigation into misleading and nuisance robocalls made to voters across Canada didn't find an intention to prevent them from casting ballots, so no one will be charged, Elections Canada says.

item.title: Measles 'early and active' in U.S.
item.description: Measles cases are at their highest level in the U.S. for this point in the year since 1996, so public health officials are urging parents to vaccinate children and are reminding health-care providers about how to recognize the illness.

item.title: Temporary Foreign Worker Program linked to joblessness, report finds
item.description: There's evidence that the government's Temporary Foreign Worker Program nudges the unemployment rate higher in some sectors of the economy and parts of the country, think-tank C.D. Howe says in a report.

item.title: Voluntary target benefit pension scheme proposed by Ottawa
item.description: A proposal to create a new voluntary target benefit pension plan, was announced by Minister of State for Finance Kevin Sorenson today in Toronto.

item.title: Ukraine clashes kill 2 as Russia ramps up military exercises
item.description: Ukrainian forces moved in and killed at least two pro-Russia insurgents in the country's tumultuous east Thursday, an escalation that prompted new threats from Russian President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Sammy Yatim killing: Const. James Forcillo back at work with TPS
item.description: The police constable charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of 18-year-old Sammy Yatim aboard a streetcar last summer has returned to work with the Toronto Police Service, despite an ongoing inquiry into the case against him.

item.title: Mount Everest climbing season in disarray as expedition teams cancel
item.description: Nepal's attempts to salvage the Mount Everest climbing season fell flat Thursday as major expedition companies cancelled their climbs and many Sherpas quit the mountain after an avalanche killed 16 of their fellow guides last week.

item.title: How medical marijuana growers make sure they're selling quality pot
item.description: The recent voluntary recall of medical marijuana from a B.C. producer highlights the growing pains of a burgeoning industry coming to grips with a whole new regulatory process.

item.title: Bangladesh's Rana Plaza factory collapse spurs change, finger-pointing
item.description: A year after the deadly Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh, families of the thousands of workers affected are still struggling with the emotional and economic fallout.

item.title: U.S. journalist Simon Ostrovsky, held in Ukraine, now free and safe
item.description: Simon Ostrovsky, the U.S. journalist who was being held by pro-Russian gunmen in eastern Ukraine, is free and safe, a Radio-Canada journalist says.

item.title: Ottawa proposes voluntary target benefit pension scheme
item.description: Minister of State for Finance Kevin Sorenson announced in Toronto today a proposal to create a new voluntary target benefit pension plan.

item.title: Pierre Poilievre to talk election law changes at Economic Club
item.description: Canada's democratic reform minister will "discuss the facts" surrounding his controversial bill to rewrite Canada's election laws during a noon-hour speech to the Economic Club of Canada in Ottawa. Kady O'Malley's live-blog now and watch CBCnews.ca's livestream of the speech starting at 12:30 p.m. ET.

item.title: Ben Heppner, star tenor, announces retirement from singing
item.description: Opera singer Ben Heppner is stepping away from the stage, the world-renowned dramatic tenor has announced.

item.title: Ottawa to propose new pension scheme, but not budging on CPP
item.description: Ottawa is preparing to announce a proposal to create yet another new pension scheme designed to occupy a middle ground between defined-benefit plans, generally favoured by workers, and defined-contribution plans favoured by employers.

item.title: Birth certificate law discriminates against transgender Albertans, judge rules
item.description: A judge has ruled that an Alberta law dealing with birth certificates violates the rights of transgender people.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Russia announces military exercises near border
item.description: Russia's defence minister announces new military exercises along the Ukrainian border just hours after Ukrainian troops killed at least two pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Prince Charles, Camilla devastated over Mark Shand's death
item.description: The Prince of Wales and his wife, Camilla, are "utterly devastated" by the death of her brother, who fell outside a hotel bar, suffering a head injury.

item.title: Is fetal tissue from B.C. used to power Oregon homes?
item.description: An Oregon county commission has ordered an incinerator to stop accepting boxed medical waste to generate electricity after learning the waste it has been burning may include tissue from aborted fetuses from British Columbia.

item.title: B.C. earthquake: 6.6-magnitude quake hits near Port Alice
item.description: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck last night shortly after 8 p.m. PT, with the epicentre located 40 kilometres southwest of Port Alice, according to the Pacific Tsunami Information Centre.

item.title: New net neutrality proposal expected from FCC
item.description: New internet rules are expected to be proposed in the U.S. that would allow content companies to pay for faster delivery over the so-called "last mile" connection to people's homes.

item.title: B.C. earthquake: 6.6 magnitude quake hits near Port Alice
item.description: A 6.6 magnitude earthquake struck Wednesday night shortly after 8 p.m. PT. The epicentre was located 40 kilometres southwest of Port Alice, according to the Pacific Tsunami Information Centre.

item.title: Jodie Foster, Alexandra Hedison get married
item.description: Jodie Foster is a married woman. The 51-year-old Oscar winner wed girlfriend Alexandra Hedison over the weekend, Foster's publicist confirmed Wednesday.
